snippet.textDisplay:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves. Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious. Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation. The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this. The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing. Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.
snippet.textOriginal:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves.  Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious.  Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation.  The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this.  The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing.  Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.

snippet.textDisplay:
@3Blue1Brown .. excellent lesson! Always enjoy your videos and your presentation..


Question, though. There are two things that I would love to see a simulation of (the one with the pie symbols slowly getting infected and feeling the growth rate).
1. When a pie recovers/dies -- what happens to the spread model? I reckon the growth rate would slow down more than it would otherwise.
2. When a pie recovers, there's still a chance to get infected again.. what happens to the spread model? I reckon the growth rate would go back up, nearly canceling out the going-down from #1.


So, how much are they affecting the growth rate? Are they already included in the (current) 15% growth rate you mention? Do they cancel each other out?


Thanks.
snippet.textOriginal:
@3Blue1Brown .. excellent lesson! Always enjoy your videos and your presentation..

2. When a pie recovers, there's still a chance to get infected again.. what happens to the spread model? I reckon the growth rate would go back up, nearly canceling out the going-down from #1.


So, how much are they affecting the growth rate? Are they already included in the (current) 15% growth rate you mention? Do they cancel each other out?


Thanks.

snippet.textDisplay:
There is no branch of mathematics, however abstract, which may not some day be applied to phenomena of the real world. —Nikolai Lobachevsky, known primarily for his work on hyperbolic geometry (aka Lobachevskian geometry) and also for his fundamental study on Dirichlet integrals, known as Lobachevsky integral formula
Without math we couldn’t have science, without science we couldn’t have technology, without technology we couldn’t have phones, radios, TVs, satellites, computers, the Internet, YouTube...and without science and technology we couldn't have medicine.
💕 ☮ 🌎 🌌
snippet.textOriginal:
_There is no branch of mathematics, however abstract, which may not some day be applied to phenomena of the real world._ —Nikolai Lobachevsky, known primarily for his work on hyperbolic geometry (aka Lobachevskian geometry) and also for his fundamental study on Dirichlet integrals, known as Lobachevsky integral formula
Without *_math_* we couldn’t have science, without science we couldn’t have technology, without technology we couldn’t have phones, radios, TVs, satellites, computers, the Internet, YouTube...and without science and technology we couldn't have medicine.
💕 ☮ 🌎 🌌

snippet.textDisplay:
It's alright to be worried, but at the same time we have to act swiftly and with precision about the issue. In italy we've been ordered to stay home in order to stop the virus spread, and we are willing to make some sacrifices if it will lead us to less trouble in the long term. In this video we've been shown that reducing the exposure with other people, and adopting proper hygiene, the virus may be contained and eventually turn the exponential curve into a logistic one.


Unfortunately there have been some setbacks with southeners living in the north returning to their homes without tests, and it may constitute a great setback for all of us.

snippet.textDisplay: Anyone know much about disease spread models? My professor said a more realistic model would be a nonlinear PDE that takes into account population movement, infection rate, and death rate of carriers. You probably can t solve it analytically and would use dynamical systems techniques to find stability of the fixed points.
snippet.textOriginal: Anyone know much about disease spread models? My professor said a more realistic model would be a nonlinear PDE that takes into account population movement, infection rate, and death rate of carriers. You probably can t solve it analytically and would use dynamical systems techniques to find stability of the fixed points.

snippet.textDisplay:
at @t=422, (7:02) the community clusters is what Italy is doing; something of a loose lockdown per city, with some control of movement between cities.
What China did is a lot stricter. A community is a city block, a much smaller subset than the city. During the lockdown, movement between city blocks was prohibited. This was enforced by controls at the entrance of each apartment building.

Better yet, switch jobs so that those already infected and no longer contagious work at popular places like LA airport for instance.

If the people that deal in physical cash are immune you will have less of a problem overloading hospital. snippet.textDisplay: Nice one, got to start with exponentials tomorrow in school. Normally i do the block standard, just draw the graph of a function that would be it´s own derivative in the positive case, the zero case and the negative case and/or spoiler the kids for integration. (show them how to integrate simple power functions and show them the idea of an infinite series. and combine that with the graph I drew to figure out it has to be exponential. and use the taylor series I derived earlier to check, if our idea is good. take the first 7-8 terms for x=1 write that down, take the first 7 to 8 terms for x=2 and check if the second is approximately the square of the first) but corona for all the hysteria there is around atm is a good more practical example. As i´m doing that class with another teacher ) I already asked him if it was okay to make the introduction longer. two lessons instead of one and utilizing the spread of corona for that. As he is also a biology teacher he actually had the same idea^^  (normally i´d use differential equations from physics to show the utility of differential equations and then proceed to define the exponential function as mentioned, but corona just lends itself to that)
snippet.textOriginal: Nice one, got to start with exponentials tomorrow in school. Normally i do the block standard, just draw the graph of a function that would be it´s own derivative in the positive case, the zero case and the negative case and/or spoiler the kids for integration. (show them how to integrate simple power functions and show them the idea of an infinite series. and combine that with the graph I drew to figure out it has to be exponential. and use the taylor series I derived earlier to check, if our idea is good. take the first 7-8 terms for x=1 write that down, take the first 7 to 8 terms for x=2 and check if the second is approximately the square of the first) but corona for all the hysteria there is around atm is a good more practical example. As i´m doing that class with another teacher ) I already asked him if it was okay to make the introduction longer. two lessons instead of one and utilizing the spread of corona for that. As he is also a biology teacher he actually had the same idea^^  (normally i´d use differential equations from physics to show the utility of differential equations and then proceed to define the exponential function as mentioned, but corona just lends itself to that)

snippet.textDisplay:
EL CORONAVIRUS Y LAS PROXIMAS PLAGAS INCURABLES
- Dios creó todo perfecto. (Gen 3:15)
- Dios creó todo para la incorruptibilidad. (Sab. 2:23)
- Todo lo creó para que subsistiera. La justicia es inmortal. (Sab. 1:14-15)
- Dios no hizo la muerte. (Rom. 5:12. Sab. 2:24).
- No fue Dios quien hizo la muerte, ni se recrea en la destrucción de los vivientes’’ (Sab. 1:13. Ezq. 33:11)
- El dolor (Gen. 3:16. Is. 1:4-5. Is. 53:3-5). La enfermedad (Prov. 18:14. Jer 10:19. Mat. 11:4). La vejez (Sab. 2:23. Salm. 71:9. Jn. 21:18) y la Muerte (Gen. 2:17. Rom. 6:23. Sant. 1:13-15) son consecuencias del pecado.
- Si desoyes la voz de Yahveh tu Dios, te sobrevendrán y te alcanzarán todas las maldiciones. Deut. 28:15-69.
- Sequías, langosta y pestes desaparecerán cuando el hombre se humille ante Dios. (2Cro. 7:13-14).
- Las cicatrices son recordatorios para que no se olviden de Dios. (Sab. 16:11-12)
- Solo Cristo Jesús es el remedio de todas las enfermedades. (Mat. 4:23-24. 8:15-17. 12:15. 14:14. Mat. 15:30-31).
- La sanación viene del cumplimiento de la Divina Voluntad. (Miq. 6:8. Sof. 2:3)
- Los demonios tratan de impedir la sanación. (Marc. 1:34).
- La oración del humilde atraviesa las nubes. (Ecco. 35:17).
- El Señor es Dios clemente, compasivo y lleno de amor. (Salm. 86:15-17. Salm. 103:8-18)
- El Señor es compasivo y misericordioso, perdona los pecados y salva en la hora de la tribulación. (Ecco. 2:11. Joel. 2:12-13)
- Los Santos son también nuestros modelos en el sufrimiento. (Sant. 5:10-11)
- La caridad, fuente de sanación. (1Ped. 3:8-12).
- Ultimas plagas incurables. (Apoc. 9:18. 11:6. 15 y 16)

En Internet encontramos “Los remedios enviados por el Cielo para los Últimos Tiempos”, que actúan solo en las almas en estado de Gracia. También, Santa HIdelgarda y los remedios naturales.
snippet.textOriginal:
EL CORONAVIRUS Y LAS PROXIMAS PLAGAS INCURABLES
- Dios creó todo perfecto. (Gen 3:15)
- Dios creó todo para la incorruptibilidad.  (Sab. 2:23)
- Todo lo creó para que subsistiera. La justicia es inmortal. (Sab. 1:14-15)
- Dios no hizo la muerte.  (Rom. 5:12.  Sab. 2:24).
- No fue Dios quien hizo la muerte, ni se recrea en la destrucción de los vivientes’’  (Sab. 1:13.  Ezq. 33:11)
- El dolor  (Gen. 3:16. Is. 1:4-5. Is. 53:3-5). La enfermedad (Prov. 18:14. Jer 10:19.  Mat. 11:4). La vejez  (Sab. 2:23. Salm. 71:9. Jn. 21:18) y la Muerte  (Gen. 2:17. Rom. 6:23. Sant. 1:13-15) son consecuencias del pecado.
- Si desoyes la voz de Yahveh tu Dios, te sobrevendrán y te alcanzarán todas las maldiciones. Deut. 28:15-69.
- Sequías, langosta y pestes desaparecerán cuando el hombre se humille ante Dios. (2Cro. 7:13-14).
- Las cicatrices son recordatorios para que no se olviden de Dios. (Sab. 16:11-12)
- Solo Cristo Jesús es el remedio de todas las enfermedades. (Mat. 4:23-24.  8:15-17.  12:15.  14:14.  Mat. 15:30-31).
- La sanación viene del cumplimiento de la Divina Voluntad. (Miq. 6:8. Sof. 2:3)
- Los demonios tratan de impedir la sanación.  (Marc. 1:34).
- La oración del humilde atraviesa las nubes.  (Ecco. 35:17).
- El Señor es Dios clemente, compasivo y lleno de amor. (Salm. 86:15-17. Salm. 103:8-18)
- El Señor es compasivo y misericordioso, perdona los pecados y salva en la hora de la tribulación.  (Ecco. 2:11. Joel. 2:12-13)
- Los Santos son también nuestros modelos en el sufrimiento.  (Sant. 5:10-11)
- La caridad, fuente de sanación.  (1Ped. 3:8-12).
- Ultimas plagas incurables. (Apoc. 9:18.  11:6.  15 y 16)

En Internet encontramos “Los remedios enviados por el Cielo para los Últimos Tiempos”, que actúan solo en las almas en estado de Gracia. También, Santa HIdelgarda y los remedios naturales.

snippet.textDisplay:
I swear, as time goes on, the comments sections on popular videos is getting increasingly bad. I remember a couple of years ago the comments under a 3blue1brown video would be chock full of maths students, mathematicians, and people genuinely interested in the content that's being delivered in the video. Now? Just take a look below. Everyone is spouting repetitive boring memes, especially in the form of "Person A: <says A>, Person B: <says B>, person C: <says C>", or "lol i'm antisocial i'm gonna stay home and watch hentai hahahaha"


I don't understand why it is that these comments make the top page every time. It's not like there weren't good content-related comments (i.e. mathematics) that were highly upvoted back in the day. Why is bullshit always making the front page? God.

snippet.textDisplay: "The only thing to fear is the lack of fear itself." Yes. But it's also worth pointing out that you cannot compensate the lack of fear among other by becoming hyperscared yourself. ;-)  So everybody should be reasonably scared. Which, I guess, boils down to: Everyone should be reasonable. Sigh.

snippet.textDisplay: Fortunately flu viruses start dying off in warmer months and we're getting into warmer months so the spread of the Coronavirus should start reducing sometime soon !!

snippet.textDisplay: Excellent presentation of the current situation with Corona.

snippet.textDisplay: Good thing we didn't go through this with the Obama Administration. He waited for a thousand deaths in America before he declared a state of emergency. Trump waited for one death before he declared a state of emergency in America. And I don't think you should be pushing fear like this. You should put the exponential growth of the common cold side by side with the one for the Coronavirus

snippet.textDisplay: Excellent! You are a didactical genius. However, the grow factor 1.15 is somehow underestimated - also countries outside China have successfully slowed the outbreak, e.g. South Korea. In Europe, the factor is almost 1.3.

snippet.textDisplay:
Why did you exclude Chinese data?
If you do the same thing with Chinese data, I believe R squared is not that high.
Try to do it with quadratic regression instead exponential regression. You would be surprised.
